title: Los Angeles (LA) Grading of Esophagitis
description: Stratifies severity of esophagitis based on endoscopic findings, recommended by ACG guidelines

parameters.name: mucosal_break_size
parameters.description: Size and extent of mucosal breaks observed on endoscopy

result.name: la_grade
result.description: Los Angeles classification grade (A, B, C, or D)

ranges.interpretation: Mucosal break(s) ≤5 mm, without continuity across mucosal folds. Mild reflux esophagitis. Treat with standard-dose PPI for 4 weeks. Consider further testing to confirm GERD diagnosis per ACG guidelines.
Mucosal break(s) >5 mm, without continuity across mucosal folds. Mild reflux esophagitis. Treat with standard-dose PPI for 4 weeks.

Mucosal break(s) continuous between ≥2 mucosal folds, involving <75% of esophageal circumference. Severe reflux esophagitis. Treat with standard-dose PPI for 8 weeks. Consider surgical options for persistent symptoms.

Mucosal break(s) involving ≥75% of esophageal circumference. Severe reflux esophagitis. Treat with standard-dose PPI for 8 weeks. Consider surgical options. Repeat endoscopy after PPI therapy to exclude Barrett's esophagus.

references: Lundell LR, Dent J, Bennett JR, Blum AL, Armstrong D, Galmiche JP, et al. Endoscopic assessment of oesophagitis: clinical and functional correlates and further validation of the Los Angeles classification. Gut. 1999 Aug;45(2):172-80. doi: 10.1136/gut.45.2.172.
Katz PO, Gerson LB, Vela MF. Guidelines for the diagnosis and management of gastroesophageal reflux disease. Am J Gastroenterol. 2013 Mar;108(3):308-28; quiz 329. doi: 10.1038/ajg.2012.444.

Kahrilas PJ, Shaheen NJ, Vaezi MF, Hiltz SW, Black E, Modlin IM, et al. American Gastroenterological Association Medical Position Statement on the management of gastroesophageal reflux disease. Gastroenterology. 2008 Oct;135(4):1383-1391, 1391.e1-5. doi: 10.1053/j.gastro.2008.05.045.
formula: Classification based on endoscopic appearance of mucosal breaks: Grade A (≤5mm, no continuity), Grade B (>5mm, no continuity), Grade C (continuous between folds, <75% circumference), Grade D (≥75% circumference).
notes: Developed to provide standardized classification of reflux esophagitis severity
Shows low interrater variability and high reproducibility
Recommended by American College of Gastroenterology (ACG) guidelines
Grades A-B considered mild reflux esophagitis (4 weeks PPI therapy)
Grades C-D considered severe reflux esophagitis (8 weeks PPI therapy)
Grade A patients may need further testing to confirm GERD diagnosis
Grade C-D patients may be candidates for antireflux surgery
Repeat endoscopy recommended after PPI therapy for severe grades to exclude Barrett's esophagus
Classification applies only to erosive esophagitis, not non-erosive reflux disease (NERD)
